moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: Philidor, Larsen variation...leads to sharp positions.
moves.6. Bg5 Bg7 7. h3 O-O 8. Qf3 h6 9. Bxf6 B: White's play seems more focused on a tactical than positional solution.
While white does have central pawns, black now has strong bishops, and can open the position.
moves.15... d5 16. exd5 Bxd5 17. Nf3 c5 18. Nx: Suddenly Black has achieved the defense's strategic goals, force white to play defensively.
moves.19. Qc2 Rad8 20. Rfd1 Re6 21. a3 Red6 22: Black chooses an aggressive approach, calculating that the more unbalanced pawn position favors black.
moves.26. Qxg5 Rd6xd3: Black decides on a risky course, 26 ... Rxd3!?. Simply 26..Qxa3 is better, since 27 Ra1 is met by ...Qb3.
moves.27. Qxd8+: 2 rooks for the queen. Black does have some dangerous queenside pawns  however.
moves.27... Rxd8 28. Rxd8+ Kg7 29. Re1 Qxa3: White has two rooks, but Black's passed pawns are menacing.
moves.30. Rb8: Whtie wants to double rooks while preventing b5, but then Black can play c4.
moves.30... c4 31. Rb7 c3 32. Ree7: Threatens pawns along the 7th rank, but Black keeps pushing the pawn.
moves.32... c2 33. Rexf7+ Kh6 34. h4: threatens checkmate, but Black has an out...
moves.41... Qcxf4: This is the right moment to sac the queen and take the rook, suddenly White's king position is fatal.
moves.42. gxf4 Qxf4+ 43. Kh1 Kxf2: White is unable to prevent checkmate, and resigns. A good example of the potential of the Philidor if White is not careful.
